          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');
        </script><head><meta charSet="utf-8"/><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"/><link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/favicon.7bc3d920.ico"/><script>

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []
        window.eventsToSend.push({
          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)

class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC Text_medium__TH6gG Text_secondary__o6d_E Likes_root__WVQ1_" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,383<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span><button type="button" class="ai-tag unstyled-button AITag_tag__Xx37c" data-cy="ai-tag" aria-describedby="aiTag-description" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3497d6:" popovertarget=":R3497d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3497d6"><span class="icon description</button><div class="" id=":R3497d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3497d6"></div></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">The document discusses adversary problems in cybersecurity, focusing on the identification and categorization of various adversary groups and their activities. It highlights notable adversaries, their motivations, and the tactics they utilize, such as spearphishing and lateral movement, while emphasizing the need for intelligence-driven security. The presentation also includes insights from CrowdStrike experts and encourages organizations to implement adversary-focused security practices.</p><div class="pills-list PillsList_root__2EydN"><a class="Pill_root__IqOYH" aria-label="View the featured presentations, documents and infographics in the Technology Category" href="https://www.slideshare.net/category/technology"><span class="icon 4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Adversary Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

CATEGORIZATION

10

Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

these adversaries

Adversary-centric perspective

Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Presentation on Implementing Blockchain (IOTA) Technology into Smart Home for later" role="switch" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfd2lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfd2lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" document presents an IoT-based smart home application utilizing IOTA distributed ledger technology to enhance security, confidentiality, integrity, and authentication. It outlines the advantages of using IOTA, such as faster transactions and scalability, compared to traditional blockchain systems. The proposed architecture successfully integrates IOTA into the smart home environment, addressing various security challenges and ensuring a decentralized control system.</span></div></div><div - Cybersecurity issues can be classified by the type of action, perpetrator, and targets

SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the FIDO (Fast Identity Online) Alliance&#x27;s mission to provide a new authentication model using public key cryptography to mitigate the security risks associated with passwords. It highlights the growing data breach problem, the advantages of FIDO authentication over traditional methods, and the need for policy evolution to support modern authentication technologies. The FIDO ecosystem currently consists of over 250 organizations and aims to enhance security, privacy, and usability across digital services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1alh7d6:" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses advanced persistent threats (APTs), which represent a significant risk to organizations&#x27; intellectual property and critical infrastructure, highlighting the necessity for effective mitigation strategies. APTs involve sophisticated and targeted hacking efforts, often starting with techniques like spear phishing, leading to complex attack lifecycles that include preparation, initial intrusion, expansion, persistence, search and exfiltration, and cleanup. The document also provides case studies of notable APT incidents, underscoring the challenges of detection and the importance of employee education and technological safeguards.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1blh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1blh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1clh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1clh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1clh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/iot-attacks-and-solutions/79173243"><span class="sr-only">IoT - It defines malware as malicious software designed to damage computers without consent. The document outlines 10 main types of malware: viruses, worms, Trojans, spyware, adware, ransomware, rootkits, keyloggers, botnets, and bugs. It also describes 3 methods of malware analysis: static analysis, which examines code without executing it; dynamic analysis, which observes behavior by running malware; and threat analysis, which identifies malware families and tracks criminal infrastructure over time.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1flh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" It defines malicious traffic as any traffic anomalies caused by hardware/software failures or intentionally modified internet packets. Several types of malicious traffic are described, including scanners, worms, spam, backscatter, and denial-of-service (DOS) attacks. Methods for detecting and preventing malicious traffic involve anomaly detection techniques, signature scanning, intrusion detection systems, quality-of-service metrics, and network filters. The conclusion emphasizes the importance of security awareness to help mitigate internet misuse.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-22" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1nlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1nlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1nlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/wso2.org/application-security-your-success-depends-on-it"><span class="sr-only">Application Security - RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses improving detection rules coverage through infrastructure automation tools, testing frameworks, and metrics. It introduces tools like Packer, Vagrant, Terraform, and DetectionLab for building detection environments. Atomic Red Team and the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework are covered for testing detections. Metrics like the ATT&amp;CK heatmap and KPIs are suggested for measuring coverage. Common pitfalls like assuming full coverage and not prioritizing are addressed.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1plh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1plh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-25" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1qlh7d6:" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Dark web</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Dark web for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdqlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdqlh7d6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfdqlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfdqlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/HASHMI007">Safwan Hashmi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The dark web allows for anonymous browsing but has privacy risks. It can only be accessed through special browsers like Tor that hide a user&#x27;s identity and location. While the dark web protects anonymity, law enforcement has found ways to de-anonymize users through vulnerabilities in the Tor network or malware. Common uses of the dark web include drugs, weapons, child pornography, and hacking tools, though it also enables whistleblowing. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are often used for transactions on the dark web due to the anonymity provided.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qlh7d6:" popover="auto" class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cybersecurity concepts including encryption, authentication, digital signatures, and penetration testing. It defines cybersecurity as protecting computer systems from threats. Encryption converts data into cipher text for protection. Authentication verifies identities through methods like passwords, certificates, and biometrics. Digital signatures mathematically verify the authenticity and integrity of messages. Penetration testing involves simulated cyber attacks to evaluate security. The document outlines security best practices and roles of security operations centers in monitoring for threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1slh7d6:" popover="auto" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the FIDO (Fast Identity Online) Alliance&#x27;s mission to provide a new authentication model using public key cryptography to mitigate the security risks associated with passwords. It highlights the growing data breach problem, the advantages of FIDO authentication over traditional methods, and the need for policy evolution to support modern authentication technologies. The FIDO ecosystem currently consists of over 250 organizations and aims to enhance security, privacy, and usability across digital services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rh69i7d6:" data-cy="slideshow-title">Advanced persistent threats(APT)</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi popovertarget=":R7mhm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mhm9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/NIIConsulting">Network Intelligence India</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses advanced persistent threats (APTs), which represent a significant risk to organizations&#x27; intellectual property and critical infrastructure, highlighting the necessity for effective mitigation strategies. APTs involve sophisticated and targeted hacking efforts, often starting with techniques like spear phishing, leading to complex attack lifecycles that include preparation, initial intrusion, expansion, persistence, search and exfiltration, and cleanup. The document also provides case studies of notable APT incidents, underscoring the challenges of detection and the importance of employee education and technological safeguards.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ri69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Ri69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ri69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/iot-attacks-and-solutions/79173243"><span class="sr-only">IoT - It notes that by 2018, digital business will require fewer workers but more digital jobs, and the cost of business operations will be reduced by 30% through automation. It also discusses new technologies like smart homes, wearables, and connected medical devices. However, the widespread connectivity of devices introduces new security threats, as many devices have poor security and collect personal data without encryption. The document calls for more robust security measures to protect the growing internet of things.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" It defines malware as malicious software designed to damage computers without consent. The document outlines 10 main types of malware: viruses, worms, Trojans, spyware, adware, ransomware, rootkits, keyloggers, botnets, and bugs. It also describes 3 methods of malware analysis: static analysis, which examines code without executing it; dynamic analysis, which observes behavior by running malware; and threat analysis, which identifies malware families and tracks criminal infrastructure over time.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" allowing enterprises to assess network threats in real-time through a 3D visualizer and receive threat intelligence reports. The POV includes installation, dedicated support, and a structured timeline with weekly meetings to review findings and progress. Data processes are passive and secure, ensuring complete control and privacy for the customer throughout the trial period.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl69i7d6:" popover="auto" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses malicious traffic on computer networks. It defines malicious traffic as any traffic anomalies caused by hardware/software failures or intentionally modified internet packets. Several types of malicious traffic are described, including scanners, worms, spam, backscatter, and denial-of-service (DOS) attacks. Methods for detecting and preventing malicious traffic involve anomaly detection techniques, signature scanning, intrusion detection systems, quality-of-service metrics, and network filters. The conclusion emphasizes the importance of security awareness to help mitigate internet misuse.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rn69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rnm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rnm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rnm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/wso2.org/application-security-your-success-depends-on-it"><span class="sr-only">Application Security - style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mp69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/HASHMI007">Safwan Hashmi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The dark web allows for anonymous browsing but has privacy risks. It can only be accessed through special browsers like Tor that hide a user&#x27;s identity and location. While the dark web protects anonymity, law enforcement has found ways to de-anonymize users through vulnerabilities in the Tor network or malware. Common uses of the dark web include drugs, weapons, child pornography, and hacking tools, though it also enables whistleblowing. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are often used for transactions on the dark web due to the anonymity provided.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the Center for Internet Security (CIS) controls and benchmarks, which are best practices for securing IT systems. The overview of benchmark recommendations highlights various sections such as identity management, networking, and logging with the number of scored and non-scored recommendations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/EngHasanShamroukh">Eng Hasan Shamroukh CISCO Exams Author</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cybersecurity concepts including encryption, authentication, digital signatures, and penetration testing. It defines cybersecurity as protecting computer systems from threats. Encryption converts data into cipher text for protection. Authentication verifies identities through methods like passwords, certificates, and biometrics. Digital signatures mathematically verify the authenticity and integrity of messages. Penetration testing involves simulated cyber attacks to evaluate security. The document outlines security best practices and roles of security operations centers in monitoring for threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq69i7d6:" popover="auto" Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mm6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mm6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mm6ai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mm6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mm6ai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bostonglobalforum">Boston Global Forum</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Common Good Digital Framework (CGDF) is a proposed campaign and platform to monitor violations of ethical values and standards related to artificial intelligence, personal data, cyber security, and digital activity by governments and large organizations. The CGDF will focus on issues like AI bias, privacy, and cyber security, and will generate policy recommendations in response to identified problems. It will utilize partners, advisors, and social media to distribute its findings and recommendations in order to influence policymaking and encourage corrective actions. The goal is to establish new ethical norms and regulations to help guide digital progress for the benefit of all humanity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rm6ai7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses the evolution of misinformation and proposes a framework called AMITT (Attribution, Mitigation, Incident and Technique Taxonomy) to analyze misinformation campaigns and incidents. It suggests populating the AMITT framework by cataloging historical misinformation examples. Finally, it notes that further work is needed to develop mitigations and counters, refine techniques, and share intelligence using the framework.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmmai7d6:" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The 2024 Australia Threat Landscape Report highlights the increasing cyber threats facing Australian entities, driven by both cybercriminals and state-sponsored actors. Key findings include a significant rise in ransomware incidents, with 99 attacks targeting Australian organizations, and a marked prevalence of phishing attacks, particularly in information services. The report emphasizes the need for robust cybersecurity measures as the threat landscape becomes more sophisticated, particularly via the dark web where compromised data is actively traded.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rnmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime  no more chewy centers- the zero trust model for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7momai7d6:" popovertarget=":R7momai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7momai7d6"><span SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes John Kindervag&#x27;s report &quot;No More Chewy Centers: The Zero Trust Model Of Information Security&quot;. The report argues that traditional perimeter-based network security models are ineffective against modern threats like targeted attacks and malicious insiders. It introduces the &quot;Zero Trust&quot; model, which considers all network traffic untrusted and requires strict access controls and monitoring. The report recommends security professionals adopt this new model to better protect their organizations from sophisticated adversaries inside and outside the network.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Romai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Romai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Rp6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp6ai7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/is-your-organization-in-crisis/72880160"><span class="sr-only">Is Your Organization in Crisis?</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Is Your Organization in Crisis?</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Is Your Organization in Crisis? privacy. class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mq6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mq6ai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The report by QRator Labs and Wallarm discusses the main trends in internet security for 2015, highlighting the increasing complexity of DDoS attacks, which often now combine multiple approaches, including application vulnerability exploits. Key findings reveal a rise in the frequency and simplicity of both DDoS and hacking attacks, with SQL injection remaining the predominant method of site hacking. The report emphasizes the need for sophisticated, continuously updated protection methods utilizing machine learning to combat these evolving threats effectively.</span></div></div><div class="" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document presents the findings of a 2017 survey conducted by ESG and commissioned by CrowdStrike, focusing on endpoint security and the buyer mindset among IT professionals across midmarket and enterprise organizations in North America. Key insights reveal that organizations are experiencing increased cyberattacks on endpoints, are planning to enhance their endpoint security investments, and show a significant shift towards adopting managed security services and endpoint detection and response solutions. Overall, the report emphasizes the need for more effective and efficient cloud-based endpoint security strategies as organizations navigate a complex and evolving threat landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses fileless attacks, which are cyber threats that do not rely on malicious executable files being written to disk and are more prevalent than traditional ransomware attacks. It explores how these attacks are conducted, including techniques like spear phishing and the use of legitimate applications for lateral movement, and emphasizes the inadequacy of traditional antivirus solutions against such methods. RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes CrowdStrike&#x27;s endpoint security product Falcon and argues that it provides more effective protection than legacy antivirus solutions. It notes that antivirus has an efficacy rate of only 45% against modern threats and is ineffective at stopping sophisticated attacks. CrowdStrike&#x27;s Falcon uses techniques like machine learning, IOAs, and threat intelligence to prevent a wider range of attacks while having a smaller system footprint than antivirus. It also provides detection capabilities like endpoint detection and response to eliminate attack dwell time. The document aims to convince readers to replace their legacy antivirus with CrowdStrike&#x27;s Falcon.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rk6bi7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the need for a balanced approach to endpoint security that includes both prevention and detection. It argues that relying solely on prevention is not sufficient, as attacks will always get through, requiring detection capabilities to identify breaches. Likewise, detection alone is insufficient, as preventing attacks upfront reduces workload. The document outlines the key components needed to properly unify next-generation antivirus and endpoint detection and response, including complete visibility of endpoint activity, large-scale analysis capacity, and the ability to derive insights and indicators of attack from collected data. An integrated approach is advocated that allows prevention and detection to strengthen one another.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mo6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mo6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mo6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the analysis of a domain generating algorithm (DGA) malware family. Key points include:

- The malware uses inline code obfuscation and encrypted strings to hide its functionality and communication domains. Researchers were able to deobfuscate the code and decrypt the strings to analyze the malware. 

- Clues in decrypted strings suggest the malware author is Romani, including references to Romani singers in template strings. 

- The malware generates domain names by concatenating two randomly selected words from a dictionary and appending &quot;.net&quot;. This allows it to generate many domain variations to communicate with its command and control servers.

- The DGA algorithm uses a 15-bit seed value derived from the</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rombi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rombi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rombi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things/25244568"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mombi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mombi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mombi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mombi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mombi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Tortilla is a free and open-source tool for Windows designed to transparently route all TCP and DNS traffic through the Tor network, preventing any internet traffic that bypasses Tor. It does not require additional hardware or virtual machines and establishes strong protections against malware circumventing the Tor tunnel. The tool is easy to install and operate, making it user-friendly and effective for maintaining privacy online.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rombi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rombi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rp6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp6bi7d6"><a Malware Family Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family Whitepaper for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mp6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mp6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mp6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mp6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mp6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document provides an overview of domain generating algorithms (DGAs) used by malware to dynamically determine remote server addresses and evade detection. It details the analysis performed on a malware family submitted to CrowdStrike, including deobfuscating the binary, analyzing its DGA and network functionality, sinkholing domains, and investigating the malware author. The family has been active for at least six years and infects thousands of devices.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpmbi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things-whitepaper/25207431"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mpmbi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mpmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mpmbi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document introduces Tortilla, software designed to allow security researchers to safely and anonymously interact with hostile servers and actors online. It discusses how traditional malware research was more passive, but now requires actively monitoring adversary infrastructure. The Tor network and Tor Browser Bundle are described as existing solutions for anonymity, but they have limitations like only supporting the Firefox browser and not plugins. Tortilla aims to address these issues by providing a more robust anonymity solution.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rq6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rq6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rq6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" Presence of Bootkits</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">I/O, You Own: Regaining Control of Your Disk in the Presence of Bootkits</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save I/O, You Own: Regaining Control of Your Disk in the Presence of Bootkits for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mq6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mq6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mq6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mq6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mq6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses a technique for regaining control of a disk in the presence of a bootkit by leveraging the crash dump stack in Windows. It provides background on the crash dump stack and how it differs from the normal I/O path. It then describes how identifying and calling the crash dump port and miniport drivers allows sending I/O requests outside of the normal path to bypass bootkit filters and read/write directly to disk. The document concludes with an overview of how this technique can be demonstrated against the TDL4 bootkit.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rq6bi7d6"></div></div><div class="desktop-recs"><div class="Slider_root__c0Jo8"><div class="Slider_scroller__KHjw4"><div SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rlmci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rlmci7d6:" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-the-sqlexecutor-for-data-quality-management-aka-one-man-s-love-for-the-sqlexecutor/280671542"><span class="sr-only">Using the SQLExecutor for Data Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:10" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using the SQLExecutor for Data Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using the SQLExecutor for Data Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mlmci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mlmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mlmci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mlmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mlmci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The SQLExecutor is one of FME’s most powerful and flexible transformers. Pivvot maintains a robust internal metadata hierarchy used to support ingestion and curation of thousands of external data sources that must be managed for quality before entering our platform. By using the SQLExecutor, Pivvot can efficiently detect problems and perform analysis before data is extracted from our staging environment, removing the need for rollbacks or cycles waisted on a failed job. This presentation will walk through three distinct examples of how Pivvot uses the SQLExecutor to engage its metadata hierarchy and integrate with its Data Quality Management workflows efficiently and within the source postgres database. Spatial Validation –Validating spatial prerequisites before entering a production environment. Reference Data Validation - Dynamically validate domain-ed columns across any table and multiple columns per table. Practical De-duplication - Removing identical or near-identical well point locations from two distinct source datasets in the same table.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rlmci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rm6ci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rm6ci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rm6ci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/2025_06_18-openmetadata-community-meeting-pdf/280768785"><span class="sr-only">2025_06_18 - OpenMetadata Community Meeting.pdf</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">2025_06_18 - OpenMetadata Community Meeting.pdf</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save 2025_06_18 - Catch the next OpenMetadata Community Meetup @ https://www.meetup.com/openmetadata-meetup-group/

In this month&#x27;s OpenMetadata Community Meetup, &quot;Enforcing Quality &amp; SLAs with OpenMetadata Data Contracts,&quot; we covered data contracts, why they matter, and how to implement them in OpenMetadata to increase the quality of your data assets! 

Agenda Highlights:
👋 Introducing Data Contracts: An agreement between data producers and consumers
📝 Data Contracts key components: Understanding a contract and its purpose
🧑‍🎨 Writing your first contract: How to create your own contracts in OpenMetadata
🦾 An OpenMetadata MCP Server update!
➕ And More!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rm6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rm6ci7d6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The OpenACC organization focuses on enhancing parallel computing skills and advancing interoperability in scientific applications through hackathons and training. The upcoming 2025 Open Accelerated Computing Summit (OACS) aims to explore the convergence of AI and HPC in scientific computing and foster knowledge sharing. This year&#x27;s OACS welcomes talk submissions from a variety of topics, from Using Standard Language Parallelism to Computer Vision Applications. The document also highlights several open hackathons, a call to apply for NVIDIA Academic Grant Program and resources for optimizing scientific applications using OpenACC directives.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rn6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn6ci7d6"></div><div class="separator Lupa.pdf</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/fwdays">Fwdays</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Design patterns like Event Sourcing and Event Streaming have long become standards for building real-time analytics systems. However, when the system load becomes nonlinear with fast and often unpredictable spikes, it&#x27;s crucial to respond quickly in order not to lose real-time operating itself.

In this talk, I’ll share my experience implementing and using a tool like Temporal.io. We&#x27;ll explore the evolution of our system for maintaining real-time report generation and discuss how we use Temporal both for short-lived pipelines and long-running background tasks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rnmci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save “MPU+: A Transformative Solution for Next-Gen AI at the Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mo6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mo6ci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/embeddedvision">Edge AI and Vision Alliance</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">For the full video of this presentation, please visit: https://www.edge-ai-vision.com/2025/06/mpu-a-transformative-solution-for-next-gen-ai-at-the-edge-a-presentation-from-fotonation/

Petronel Bigioi, CEO of FotoNation, presents the “MPU+: A Transformative Solution for Next-Gen AI at the Edge” tutorial at the May 2025 Embedded Vision Summit.

In this talk, Bigioi introduces MPU+, a novel programmable, customizable low-power platform for real-time, localized intelligence at the edge. The platform includes an AI-augmented image signal processor that enables leading image and video quality.

In addition, it integrates ultra-low-power object and motion detection capabilities to enable always-on computer vision. A programmable neural processor provides flexibility to efficiently implement new neural networks. And additional specialized engines facilitate image stabilization and audio enhancements.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro6ci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Romci7d6:" popovertarget=":Romci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Romci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A From Generative AI to Global AI networks to Martian Colonisation to Interstellar exploration to Industrial Nanotechnology to Artificial Consciousness, this is a journey you don&#x27;t want to miss. Which ones excite you the most? Which ones are you apprehensive about? Feel free to comment! Let the conversation begin!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Romci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Romci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp6ci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rp6ci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp6ci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/eis-webinar-engineering-retail-infrastructure-06-16-2025-pdf/280769110"><span class="sr-only">EIS-Webinar-Engineering-Retail-Infrastructure-06-16-2025.pdf</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">EIS-Webinar-Engineering-Retail-Infrastructure-06-16-2025.pdf</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save EIS-Webinar-Engineering-Retail-Infrastructure-06-16-2025.pdf for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mp6ci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mp6ci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mp6ci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mp6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mp6ci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Earley">Earley Information Science</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As AI reshapes expectations in retail and B2B commerce, organizations are recognizing a critical reality: meaningful AI outcomes depend on well-structured, adaptable infrastructure. In this session, Seth Earley is joined by Phil Ryan - AI strategist, search technologist, and founder of Glass Leopard Technologies - for a candid conversation on what it truly means to engineer systems for scale, agility, and intelligence.

Phil draws on more than two decades of experience leading search and AI initiatives for enterprise organizations. Together, he and Seth explore the challenges businesses face when legacy architectures limit personalization, agility, and real-time decisioning - and what needs to change to support agentic technologies and next-best-action capabilities.

Key themes from the webinar include:

Composability as a prerequisite for AI - Why modular, loosely coupled systems are essential for adapting to rapid innovation and evolving business needs

Search and relevance as foundational to AI - How techniques honed-in enterprise search have laid the groundwork for more responsive and intelligent customer experiences

From MDM and CDP to agentic systems - How data platforms are evolving to support richer customer context and dynamic orchestration

Engineering for business alignment - Why successful AI programs require architectural decisions grounded in measurable outcomes

The conversation is practical and forward-looking, connecting deep technical understanding with real-world business needs. Whether you’re modernizing your commerce stack or exploring how AI can enhance product discovery, personalization, or customer journeys, this session provides a clear-eyed view of the capabilities, constraints, and priorities that matter most.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp6ci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpmci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpmci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/smarter-aviation-data-management-lessons-from-swedavia-airports-and-sweco/280714317"><span class="sr-only">Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mpmci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mpmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mpmci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mpmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mpmci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Managing airport and airspace data is no small task, especially when you’re expected to deliver it in AIXM format without spending a fortune on specialized tools. But what if there was a smarter, more affordable way?

Join us for a behind-the-scenes look at how Sweco partnered with Swedavia, the Swedish airport operator, to solve this challenge using FME and Esri.

Learn how they built automated workflows to manage periodic updates, merge airspace data, and support data extracts – all while meeting strict government reporting requirements to the Civil Aviation Administration of Sweden.

Even better? Swedavia built custom services and applications that use the FME Flow REST API to trigger jobs and retrieve results – streamlining tasks like securing the quality of new surveyor data, creating permdelta and baseline representations in the AIS schema, and generating AIXM extracts from their AIS data.

To conclude, FME expert Dean Hintz will walk through a GeoBorders reading workflow and highlight recent enhancements to FME’s AIXM (Aeronautical Information Exchange Model) processing and interpretation capabilities.

Discover how airports like Swedavia are harnessing the power of FME to simplify aviation data management, and how you can too.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpmci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Who’s Targeting You and Why?

Today’s </a> Speakers
ADAM MEYERS |
VP, INTELLIGENCE

of cyber security industry experience

ranging from wireless, pen testing, IR, and malware analysis

 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#4">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

4

 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#5">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries </a> are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

formation of TCA

compromise of US financial

participation in

announces new personal page

Authorities

compromise databases at target
organizations.

 </li></div><div><li>30. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#30">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

30

 </li></div><div><li>31. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#31">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

31

 </li></div><div><li>32. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#32">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversary </a> Microsite
COMING SOON
TRACK: Track current
Adversaries against other
Industry nomenclature
OVERVIEW: Gain insight
Into adversary – new groups
Added weekly

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

32

 </li></div><div><li>33. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#33">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

It provides background on the crash dump stack and how it differs from the normal I/O path. It then describes how identifying and calling the crash dump port and miniport drivers allows sending I/O requests outside of the normal path to bypass bootkit filters and read/write directly to disk. The document concludes with an overview of how this technique can be demonstrated against the TDL4 bootkit.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/io-you-own-regaining-control-of-your-disk-in-the-presence-of-bootkits/15921485","userLogin":"CrowdStrike","userName":"CrowdStrike","viewCount":5377}],"featured":null,"latest":[{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"Raman Bhaumik - Passionate Tech Enthusiast","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":8,"score":0,"slideshowId":"280607411","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"raman-bhaumik-passionate-tech-enthusiast","extension":"pdf","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/ramanbhaumik-passionatetechenthusiast-250616072223-1ed62280-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"A Junior Software Developer with a flair for innovation, Raman Bhaumik excels in delivering scalable web solutions. SQLExecutor is one of FME’s most powerful and flexible transformers. Pivvot maintains a robust internal metadata hierarchy used to support ingestion and curation of thousands of external data sources that must be managed for quality before entering our platform. By using the SQLExecutor, Pivvot can efficiently detect problems and perform analysis before data is extracted from our staging environment, removing the need for rollbacks or cycles waisted on a failed job.
